messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 59 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Mirror Descent for Stochastic Control Problems with measure-valued controls

Paper Abstract: Abstract. This paper studies the convergence of the mirror descent algorithm for finite horizon stochastic control problems with measure-valued control processes. The control objective involves a convex regularisation function, denoted as h‚Ñéh, with regularisation strength determined by the weight œÑ‚â•0ùúè0\tau\geq 0. The setting covers regularised relaxed control problems. Under suitable conditions, we establish the relative smoothness and convexity of the control objective with respect to the Bregman divergence of h‚Ñéh, and prove linear convergence of the algorithm for œÑ=0ùúè0\tau=0 and exponential convergence for œÑ>0ùúè0\tau>0. The results apply to common regularisers including relative entropy, œá2superscriptùúí2\chi^{2}-divergence, and entropic Wasserstein costs. This validates recent reinforcement learning heuristics that adding regularisation accelerates the convergence of gradient methods. The proof exploits careful regularity estimates of backward stochastic differential equations in the bounded mean oscillation norm.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 59 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 59"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Mirror descent with relative smoothness in measure spaces, with application to Sinkhorn and EM",
        "Logarithmic regret for episodic continuous-time linear-quadratic reinforcement learning over a finite-time horizon",
        "A descent lemma beyond Lipschitz gradient continuity: first-order methods revisited and applications",
        "A fast iterative shrinkage-thresholding algorithm for linear inverse problems",
        "The theory of optimal processes. i. the maximum principle",
        "Perturbation analysis of optimization problems",
        "Doubly regularized entropic Wasserstein barycenters",
        "Linear and nonlinear functional analysis with applications",
        "Eine informationstheoretische Ungleichung und ihre Anwendung auf Beweis der Ergodizitaet von Markoffschen Ketten",
        "A forward‚Äìbackward stochastic algorithm for quasi-linear pdes",
        "The rate of convergence of finite-difference approximations for parabolic Bellman equations with Lipschitz coefficients in cylindrical domains",
        "Numerical methods for forward-backward stochastic differential equations",
        "A weak convergence approach to the theory of large deviations",
        "Interpolating between optimal transport and MMD using Sinkhorn divergences",
        "Convergence of policy gradient methods for finite-horizon stochastic linear-quadratic control problems",
        "Infinite dimensional analysis",
        "Reinforcement learning for linear-convex models with jumps via stability analysis of feedback controls",
        "Towards an analytical framework for potential games",
        "On finite-difference approximations for normalized Bellman equations",
        "Reinforcement learning with deep energy-based policies",
        "Deep learning-based numerical methods for high-dimensional parabolic partial differential equations and backward stochastic differential equations",
        "Convergence of the deep BSDE method for coupled FBSDEs",
        "A stability approach for solving multidimensional quadratic BSDEs",
        "Convergence of policy improvement for entropy-regularized stochastic control problems",
        "A neural network-based policy iteration algorithm with global H2superscriptùêª2H^{2}-superlinear convergence for stochastic games on domains",
        "Three algorithms for solving high-dimensional fully coupled FBSDEs through deep learning",
        "A modified method of successive approximations for stochastic recursive optimal control problems",
        "Policy gradient and actor-critic learning in continuous time and space: Theory and algorithms",
        "Central limit theorem over non-linear functionals of empirical measures with applications to the mean-field fluctuation of interacting diffusions",
        "Polynomial approximation of high-dimensional Hamilton‚ÄìJacobi‚ÄìBellman equations and applications to feedback control of semilinear parabolic PDEs",
        "Continuous exponential martingales and BMO",
        "A Fisher‚ÄìRao gradient flow for entropy-regularised Markov decision processes in Polish spaces",
        "Exponential convergence and stability of Howard‚Äôs policy improvement algorithm for controlled diffusions",
        "A modified MSA for stochastic control problems",
        "Controlled diffusion processes",
        "Policy mirror descent for reinforcement learning: Linear convergence, new sampling complexity, and generalized problem classes",
        "Maximum principle based algorithms for deep learning",
        "Relatively smooth convex optimization by first-order methods, and applications",
        "On numerical approximations of forward-backward stochastic differential equations",
        "Leveraging non-uniformity in first-order non-convex optimization",
        "On the global convergence rates of softmax policy gradient methods",
        "Discretization of forward‚Äìbackward stochastic differential equations and related quasi-linear parabolic equations",
        "Compactification methods in the control of degenerate diffusions: existence of an optimal control",
        "On the criterion that a given system of deviations from the probable in the case of a correlated system of variables is such that it can be reasonably supposed to have arisen from random sampling",
        "Mathematical theory of optimal processes",
        "A posteriori error estimates for fully coupled McKean-Vlasov forward-backward SDEs",
        "Linear convergence of a policy gradient method for some finite horizon continuous time control problems",
        "Regularity and stability of feedback relaxed controls",
        "Proximal policy optimization algorithms",
        "The modified MSA, a gradient flow and convergence",
        "DGM: A deep learning algorithm for solving partial differential equations",
        "Gradient flows for regularized stochastic control problems",
        "Reinforcement learning: An introduction",
        "Exploration-exploitation trade-off for continuous-time episodic reinforcement learning with linear-convex models",
        "Optimal scheduling of entropy regulariser for continuous-time linear-quadratic reinforcement learning",
        "Exploration versus exploitation in reinforcement learning: A stochastic control approach",
        "Reinforcement learning in continuous time and space: A stochastic control approach",
        "Continuous-time mean‚Äìvariance portfolio selection: A reinforcement learning framework",
        "Backward stochastic differential equations"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 59 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Mirror Descent for Stochastic Control Problems with measure-valued controls, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
